awd_titl_txt: Modeling and Stochastic Simulation of Close-Contact Dynamics in Immune Recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
The project supported under this award will use mathematics to understand how the immune system is able to locate and fend off threats. White blood cells known as T cells are a key component of the immune system. Their responsibility is to search for relatively rare molecular signatures of pathogens. Autoimmune, immunodeficient diseases and cancer arise from a failure of this mechanism. The basic principles of how T cells efficiently discriminate between rare foreign cells and abundant host cells is not completely understood. This project will develop a new generation of theoretical and computational tools to massively accelerate the random sampling of T cell activation times. Working with experimental collaborators, the project will explore (through mathematical modeling, stochastic analysis and large scale computational simulations) the role that the cell-to-cell contact topography plays in immune recognition. This award will support undergraduate and graduate student researchers to work on this project. This project will reach the broader mathematical community through mini-symposia at upcoming conferences and thematic workshops hosted by the American Mathematical Society.

When T cells encounter a cell of interest, they scan its surface for rare diffusing signaling molecules. This search is conducted in a bustling and noisy environment and so T cell activation is a stochastic process described mathematically as a first passage problem. Previous mathematical models of this process assumed the interface between the cells was large and contiguous. Recent experimental work has revealed that T cells extend numerous finger-like projections called microvilli to sculpt a highly transient and distributed interface. This project will build new models of T cell activation that incorporate the recently discovered role of stochastic topography arising from microvilli sampling. Much existing first passage theory has focused on determination of the mean of the distribution. Owing to the sensitivity of T cell activation, this project will require the development of new probabilistic tools to obtain the full distribution of passage times in a variety of narrow escape problems. To complement these theoretical results, the proposal will develop a new suite of computational (deterministic and Monte-Carlo) tools for studying stochastic processes in dynamic and heterogeneous environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview of outcomes: The outcomes of this project were advancements to our understanding of stochastic signaling processes in the immune system. Specifically, this proposal addressed the long standing conundrum of how the immune system can be simultaneously exquisitely sensitive to rare molecular signatures of pathogens, and completely non-reactive to abundant but chemically similar signals from healthy cells - a phenomenon known as antigen discrimination. The PI worked together with mathematical and biological collaborators to establish new models for predicting immunological outcomes and novel mathematical tools for their simulation and analysis.

Overview of intellectual merits: 

This work identified new mechanisms on how the cell surface topography can influence positive outcomes in immunological signaling. When two cells meet across a physical interface, a rapid and precise exchange of information occurs from which an immune response may be initiated. The topography between immune cells and their surveillance targets, together with the duration of this handshake, play hitherto unexplained roles in immune signaling. This proposal developed new anatomically informed mathematical models to predict the role of complex topography and the duration of this interface. Our model predicts that 1. stochastic topography balances both scanning speed of with accuracy, 2. the duration of immune handshakes must be tightly controlled in order to reduce false positive outcomes in immune activation

Mathematically, the PI lead a team of students and collaborators to develop a suite of analytical and computational methods for extracting useful predictions from stochastic models. This included asymptotic methods for approximating the first passage time distributions of rare events and acceleration methods to enable their rapid sampling.

Overview of broader impacts: The impacts of this research reach beyond the immune system to scenarios where biological agents communicate in noisy or stochastic fashion to achieve deterministic reliability. Examples of related biological systems are the directed motion of white blood cells up chemical gradients or the navigation of male moths to female mates through noisy pheromone plumes. 

The project involved the training of one post-doctoral fellow, two Ph.D students and four undergraduate researchers. The outcomes of the project have appeared in ten peer-reviewed journal publications in both specialist and broad scope journals. Educational outcomes include the development of new courses and undergraduate research projects. The outcomes of the research have been further disseminated at numerous international conferences.
